intro: Papaver uschakovii subsp. tichomirovii, commonly known as the Tichomirov's poppy, is a rare and endemic species native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its striking, vibrant red flowers with a distinctive orange center, which bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its leaves are palmately lobed and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are sturdy and often branched. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species requiring conservation efforts.
